changes: Updated experiment status from PENDING to COMPLETED
Populated benchmark results with actual performance measurements
Added detailed analysis and performance breakdowns

patterns_discovered: Welford algorithm has higher per-element computational overhead compared to sliding window approaches
Single-pass algorithms do not guarantee performance improvements
Numerical stability comes with significant performance trade-offs
Memory bandwidth is not always the primary performance bottleneck
gotchas_discovered: Fused Welford approach was 2.8× slower than separate implementations
Division operations in Welford algorithm are expensive (15-20 CPU cycles)
Sum-of-squares approach can be faster than more numerically stable methods

approach_outcome.hypothesis: Fused single-pass algorithm would improve performance

recommendations: Keep separate SMA and rolling_stddev implementations
Consider sum-of-squares approach for performance-critical scenarios
Document performance trade-offs between numerical stability and speed
Evaluate fusion strategies on a case-by-case basis
Look for performance gains in other computational kernels
